paragraphs.text:
%md # Binary Classification Algorithms with Pipelines API Name(s): _

CoralieNagy

_ Class: _

BIBD

_
In this notebook, we will test out the Binary Classification algorithms available in the ML Pipelines API using the Adult dataset. The Pipelines API provides higher-level API built on top of DataFrames for constructing ML pipelines. You can read more about the ML Pipelines API in the [programming guide](http://spark.apache.org/docs/2.0.1/ml-guide.html). **Binary Classification** is the task of predicting a binary 0 or 1 label. E.g., is an email spam or not spam? Should I show this ad to this user or not? Will it rain tomorrow or not? This notebook demonstrates several algorithms for making these types of predictions.
This notebook will act as your written assignment. As such, it should contain your code and all necessary explanations, like why did you use that or why do you think this happens. When I read it at the end, I should understand all of your reasoning. Don't forget to __frequently__ commit your code and push it back to Github. A good advice would be that anytime your answer a question with code and explanation, you should commit a message referencing the question and push it to Github. By versioning frequently, you keep a good history of your work and can eventually return back. At the end of the assignment, you will notify me of your work via a pull request. Your mark will be based on: - your commit activity - completing the full analysis of the dataset, from describing it to predicting the income value and evaluating that The questions I have put serve as a guideline, but you are totally free to change the text and put your own descriptions (which is absolutely appreciated because it shows you have fully comprehended the problem)
####Table of Contents * Dataset Review * Load Data * Descriptive analysis * Data Preprocessing * Creation of models * Conclusion

paragraphs.text:
%md

## I. Dataset review

The Adult dataset is publicly available at the [UCI Machine Learning Repository](https://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/datasets/Adult). This data was obtained from the Census, and consists of information about 48842 individuals and their annual income. We will use this information to predict if an individual earns >50k a year or <=50K a year. The dataset is rather clean, and consists of both numeric and categorical variables.

Attribute Information:
- age: continuous
- workclass: Private, Self-emp-not-inc, Self-emp-inc, Federal-gov, Local-gov, State-gov, Without-pay, Never-worked
- fnlwgt: continuous
- education: Bachelors, Some-college, 11th, HS-grad, Prof-school, Assoc-acdm, Assoc-voc...
- education-num: continuous
- marital-status: Married-civ-spouse, Divorced, Never-married, Separated, Widowed, Married-spouse-absent...
- occupation: Tech-support, Craft-repair, Other-service, Sales, Exec-managerial, Prof-specialty, Handlers-cleaners...
- relationship: Wife, Own-child, Husband, Not-in-family, Other-relative, Unmarried
- race: White, Asian-Pac-Islander, Amer-Indian-Eskimo, Other, Black
- sex: Female, Male. 
- capital-gain: continuous
- capital-loss: continuous
- hours-per-week: continuous
- native-country: United-States, Cambodia, England, Puerto-Rico, Canada, Germany...


Target/Label:
- <=50K, >50K

paragraphs.title: Load data (run the cell)
paragraphs.text:
import org.apache.spark.sql.types.{StringType, DoubleType, StructType, StructField}

val schema = StructType(Seq(
    StructField("age", DoubleType),
    StructField("workclass", StringType),
    StructField("fnlwgt", DoubleType),
    StructField("education", StringType),
    StructField("education_num", DoubleType),
    StructField("marital_status", StringType),
    StructField("occupation", StringType),
    StructField("relationship", StringType),
    StructField("race", StringType),
    StructField("sex", StringType),
    StructField("capital_gain", DoubleType),
    StructField("capital_loss", DoubleType),
    StructField("hours_per_week", DoubleType),
    StructField("native_country", StringType),
    StructField("income", StringType)
    ))

case class Adult(
    age: Double, 
    workclass: String, 
    fnlwgt: Double, 
    education: String, 
    education_num: Double, 
    marital_status: String, 
    occupation: String, 
    relationship: String, 
    race: String, 
    sex: String, 
    capital_gain: Double, 
    capital_loss: Double, 
    hours_per_week: Double, 
    native_country: String, 
    income: String
    )
    
val dataset = spark.read.schema(schema).csv("/opt/dataset/adult.data.csv").as[Adult]
dataset.registerTempTable("dataset")  // register it so we can use it inside %sql interpreter

paragraphs.text:
%md ## III. Descriptive analysis

Exercise

Provide a summary statistics graph for some columns you deem interesting. Summary statistics is comprised (but not limited) of: * mean, standard deviation and skewness for numeric columns. * counts and percentage of each value for categorical columns. If you can, try to separate the two income groups and compare. Two ways of doing this: * You should be able to it using standard SQL queries on the DataFrame and `show()` the result * You can use the %sql interpreter like in the previous cell and then use the settings tab of your graph to display the desired results. _

EXERCICE:

_ I chose to show the gap between the number of employed people who are Male/female and between different races by type of occupation and for the same level of education. We saw that White male are more employed for high occupation.

result.msg:
III. Descriptive analysis

Exercise

Provide a summary statistics graph for some columns you deem interesting. Summary statistics is comprised (but not limited) of:

  • mean, standard deviation and skewness for numeric columns.
  • counts and percentage of each value for categorical columns.

If you can, try to separate the two income groups and compare.

Two ways of doing this:

  • You should be able to it using standard SQL queries on the DataFrame and show() the result
  • You can use the %sql interpreter like in the previous cell and then use the settings tab of your graph to display the desired results.

EXERCICE:

I chose to show the gap between the number of employed people who are Male/female and between different races by type of occupation and for the same level of education. We saw that White male are more employed for high occupation.

paragraphs.text:
%md 

## IV. Data preprocessing

Since we are going to try algorithms like Logistic Regression, we will have to convert the categorical variables in the dataset into numeric variables. There are 2 ways we can do this.

- Category Indexing. This is basically assigning a numeric value to each category from {0, 1, 2, ...numCategories-1}. This introduces an implicit ordering among your categories, and is more suitable for ordinal variables (eg: Poor: 0, Average: 1, Good: 2)
- [One-Hot Encoding](http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/ml-features.html#onehotencoder). This converts categories into binary vectors with at most one positive value (eg: (Blue: 1, 0, 0), (Green: 0, 1, 0), (Red: 0, 0, 1))

result.msg:
IV. Data preprocessing

Since we are going to try algorithms like Logistic Regression, we will have to convert the categorical variables in the dataset into numeric variables. There are 2 ways we can do this.

  • Category Indexing. This is basically assigning a numeric value to each category from {0, 1, 2, …numCategories-1}. This introduces an implicit ordering among your categories, and is more suitable for ordinal variables (eg: Poor: 0, Average: 1, Good: 2)
  • One-Hot Encoding. This converts categories into binary vectors with at most one positive value (eg: (Blue: 1, 0, 0), (Green: 0, 1, 0), (Red: 0, 0, 1))

paragraphs.title: One-hot encoding example
paragraphs.text:
val names = Seq("color", "index", "OHE_attr1", "OHE_attr2", "OHE_attr3")
sqlContext.createDataFrame(sc.parallelize(Seq(("Blue", 0, 1, 0, 0), ("Green", 1, 0, 1, 0), ("Red", 2, 0 , 0 , 1)))).toDF(names: _*).show()

%md In this dataset, we have ordinal variables like education (Preschool - Doctorate), and also nominal variables like relationship (Wife, Husband, Own-child, etc). For simplicity's sake, we will use One-Hot Encoding to convert all categorical variables into binary vectors. It might be possible here to improve prediction accuracy by converting each categorical column with an appropriate method. Here, we will use a combination of [StringIndexer](http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/ml-features.html#stringindexer) and [OneHotEncoder](http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/ml-features.html#onehotencoder) on each string column to convert the categorical variables. The `OneHotEncoder` will return a SparseVector (which means, for `(8,[4],[1.0])` that the vector has size 8, one only the 4th column contains a value which is 1.0). Since we will have many stages of feature transformations, we use an [ML Pipeline](http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/ml-pipeline.html) to tie the stages together. This simplifies our code. You should especially try to use [the Pipeline example](http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/ml-pipeline.html#example-pipeline). ```scala // Configure an ML pipeline, which consists of two stages on one column: a StringIndexer and a OneHotEncoder. import org.apache.spark.ml.feature.{OneHotEncoder, StringIndexer} import org.apache.spark.ml.{Pipeline, PipelineModel} // stages for column workclass val stringIndexer = new StringIndexer() .setInputCol("workclass") .setOutputCol("workclassIndex") val oneHotEncoder = new OneHotEncoder() .setInputCol(stringIndexer.getOutputCol) .setOutputCol(stringIndexer.getInputCol + "ClassVec") // stage for label val label_stringIdx = new StringIndexer() .setInputCol("income") .setOutputCol("label") val stages = Seq(stringIndexer, oneHotEncoder) ++ Seq(label_stringIdx) // concatenate 2 sequences of stages val pipeline = new Pipeline() .setStages(stages.toArray) val pipelineModel = pipeline.fit(dataset) pipelineModel.transform(dataset).show() ``` It is also a good time to transform the income to a label of 0 and 1 for binary classification using the `StringIndexer`.

Exercise

1. For each categorical column, build a stage of StringIndexer and OneHotEncoder 2. Add all those stages in a single pipeline 3. Also add a StringIndexer of the `income` column and name the output column `label` 3. Check the result by passing your dataset inside the pipeline. Comment & explain. _Hint: actually map your sequence of categorical columns to a sequence of stages through FP._

result.msg:
In this dataset, we have ordinal variables like education (Preschool - Doctorate), and also nominal variables like relationship (Wife, Husband, Own-child, etc). For simplicity's sake, we will use One-Hot Encoding to convert all categorical variables into binary vectors. It might be possible here to improve prediction accuracy by converting each categorical column with an appropriate method.

Here, we will use a combination of StringIndexer and OneHotEncoder on each string column to convert the categorical variables. The OneHotEncoder will return a SparseVector (which means, for (8,[4],[1.0]) that the vector has size 8, one only the 4th column contains a value which is 1.0).

Since we will have many stages of feature transformations, we use an ML Pipeline to tie the stages together. This simplifies our code. You should especially try to use the Pipeline example.

// Configure an ML pipeline, which consists of two stages on one column: a StringIndexer and a OneHotEncoder.
import org.apache.spark.ml.feature.{OneHotEncoder, StringIndexer}
import org.apache.spark.ml.{Pipeline, PipelineModel}

// stages for column workclass
val stringIndexer = new StringIndexer()
  .setInputCol("workclass")
  .setOutputCol("workclassIndex")
val oneHotEncoder = new OneHotEncoder()
  .setInputCol(stringIndexer.getOutputCol)
  .setOutputCol(stringIndexer.getInputCol + "ClassVec")

// stage for label
val label_stringIdx = new StringIndexer()
    .setInputCol("income")
    .setOutputCol("label")

val stages =  Seq(stringIndexer, oneHotEncoder) ++ Seq(label_stringIdx) // concatenate 2 sequences of stages
val pipeline = new Pipeline()
  .setStages(stages.toArray)

val pipelineModel = pipeline.fit(dataset)
pipelineModel.transform(dataset).show()

It is also a good time to transform the income to a label of 0 and 1 for binary classification using the StringIndexer.

%md To run machine learning on a dataset, you need a column which contains a vector of all the features, and a column with the label. We use the [VectorAssembler](http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/ml-features.html#vectorassembler) to assemble all of our numeric columns and one-hot encoded categorical columns into one.

Exercise

Add the `VectorAssembler` stage, which takes as input all numeric columns and one hot encoded categorical columns. The `features` column will then be created. You can comment on it.

To run machine learning on a dataset, you need a column which contains a vector of all the features, and a column with the label.

We use the VectorAssembler to assemble all of our numeric columns and one-hot encoded categorical columns into one.

Exercise

Add the VectorAssembler stage, which takes as input all numeric columns and one hot encoded categorical columns. The features column will then be created. You can comment on it.

paragraphs.text:
// Code 1 + code 2

import org.apache.spark.ml.feature.{OneHotEncoder, StringIndexer}
import org.apache.spark.ml.{Pipeline, PipelineModel}
import org.apache.spark.ml.feature.VectorAssembler
import org.apache.spark.ml.linalg.Vectors

val CatStages=categoricalCols.flatMap{s =>
val stringIndexer = new StringIndexer()
  .setInputCol(s)
  .setOutputCol(s+"index")
val oneHotEncoder = new OneHotEncoder()
  .setInputCol(stringIndexer.getOutputCol)
  .setOutputCol(stringIndexer.getInputCol + "ClassVec")
  
  Seq(stringIndexer,oneHotEncoder)
}

val label_stringIdx = new StringIndexer()
    .setInputCol("income")
    .setOutputCol("label")
 
val AssCol = numericCols ++ categoricalCols.map(c => c + "ClassVec" ) // on concène les 2 sortes de colonnes numériques et catéorielles ajoutées à Class Vec 
val assembler = new VectorAssembler()
  .setInputCols(AssCol.toArray)
  .setOutputCol("features")

val stages =  CatStages ++ Seq(label_stringIdx) ++ Seq(assembler) // concatenate 2 sequences of stages
val pipeline = new Pipeline()
  .setStages(stages.toArray)

val pipelineModel = pipeline.fit(dataset)
pipelineModel.transform(dataset).show()

%md ## V. Creation of models We are now ready to try out some of the Binary Classification Algorithms available in the new ML Pipelines API. We have the choice between: - [Binomial Logistic regression](http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/ml-classification-regression.html#binomial-logistic-regression) - [Decision trees](http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/ml-classification-regression.html#decision-trees) - [Random forest](http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/ml-classification-regression.html#random-forests) These are the general steps we will take to build our models: - Create the initial model on the training set - Use your model to make predictions on your testing set - Evaluate the quality of your predictions We will be using the `BinaryClassificationEvaluator` to evaluate our models. The default metric used here is [areaUnderROC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Receiver_operating_characteristic#Area_under_the_curve).

Exercise

1. Fit your data on one of the three Machine Learning models on the training dataset. This should create an Estimator. 2. Run the estimator on the testing dataset to create a prediction column 3. Use `BinaryClassificationEvaluator.evaluate()` to evaluate your predictions.

V. Creation of models

We are now ready to try out some of the Binary Classification Algorithms available in the new ML Pipelines API.

We have the choice between:

  • Binomial Logistic regression
  • Decision trees
  • Random forest

These are the general steps we will take to build our models:

  • Create the initial model on the training set
  • Use your model to make predictions on your testing set
  • Evaluate the quality of your predictions

We will be using the BinaryClassificationEvaluator to evaluate our models. The default metric used here is areaUnderROC.

Exercise

  1. Fit your data on one of the three Machine Learning models on the training dataset. This should create an Estimator.
  2. Run the estimator on the testing dataset to create a prediction column
  3. Use BinaryClassificationEvaluator.evaluate() to evaluate your predictions.
